newsitem.title: SRI LANKA: Twelve killed in clashes in northeast Sri Lanka.
newsitem.headline: Twelve killed in clashes in northeast Sri Lanka.

text.p: At least 12 Tamil Tiger rebels and government soldiers were killed in separate clashes in Sri Lanka's northeast over the weekend, military officials said on Sunday.

An army foot patrol on Saturday afternoon ambushed a group of Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam rebels near Weli Oya, about 240 km (150 miles) from the capital Colombo, killing four rebels and recovering their weapons, they said.
But another group of rebels ambushed the patrol as it returned to base, killing three soldiers and wounding 13, they said.

In eastern Batticaloa district the same day, rebels blew up an army armoured vehicle with a rocket-propelled grenade, killing two soldiers, while 19 soldiers and a civilian were wounded when a landmine exploded near their convoy, officials said.
Two local home guard militiamen also were killed and two wounded when rebels attacked the Kantale police post, 200 km (125 miles) northeast of Colombo early on Sunday, they said.
One of the rebels, who are fighting for an independent homeland for minority Tamils in the north and east of this Indian Ocean island, died in the raid, they added.
Government troops hunting the Tigers in the Batticaloa jungles last week destroyed two abandoned rebel bases.
The Tigers were not immediately available for comment on the military's reports of the latest clashes.
The Tigers said in a statement last week that they had lost more than 9,000 cadres in their war for independence, now in its 14th year.
The government says more than 50,000 people have died in the war. The rebels say the toll is much higher.
